Caption: The chief guest Mr. C. Subramaniam is escorted by Dr. A. L. Mudaliar, Chairman, Board of Governors and Prof. B. Sengupto, Director
Description: From left: (third from left) chief guest Mr. C. Subramaniam (Minister of Education, Law and Finance for Madras State) is escorted by (second from left) Dr. A. L. Mudaliar, Chairman, Board of Governors and (extreme right) Prof. B. Sengupto, Director. Chidambaram Subramaniam (also known as CS), was an Indian politician and activist. He was born in Senguttaipalayam village near Pollachi, in Coimbatore district in 1910. He completed his early education in Pollachi, and then moved to Chennai to do B.Sc. in Physics at Presidency College. He later graduated with a law degree from Madras Law College. When he visited IIT Madras in 1961, he was the Minister of Education, Law and Finance for Madras State (1952 to 1962). In his political career, He served as Minister of Finance (1975 to 1977) and Minister of Defence (1979 to 1980) in the union cabinet, as Governor of Maharashtra (1990 to 1993), Minister for Food and Agriculture (1964 to 1966) and also worked as the Deputy Chairman of the Planning Commission (1971 to 1972). Subramaniam was one of the architects of India's modern agricultural development policy, which led to the ‘Indian Green Revolution’. He was a recipient of the Bharat Ratna in 1998. Prof. Bibhutibhushan Sengupto was the first Director of IIT Madras. He played a pivotal role in the rapid growth that took place during the initial years of the Institute. Most of his earlier education took place in East Bengal and Calcutta. He studied at the Benaras Hindu University which was one of the leading universities at that time, known for its engineering education. He then went to Manchester, England for further education. Prof B. Sengupto was selected to be founder Director of IIT Madras in 1958, and he joined IIT Madras in 1959. Dr. A. L. Mudaliar completed his education from Madras Christian College, after which he joined Madras Medical College to study medicine. He served as the first Indian principal of Madras Medical College in 1939, after having completed his specialisation in obstetrics and gynaecology (O&G). He later served as Vice Chancellor of Madras University for a period of 27 years. He was also the Deputy Leader of the Indian delegation to the First World Health Assembly in Geneva in 1948. Following this, Mudaliar was elected as the chairman of the World Health Organization (WHO) Executive Board in 1949 and 1950. Apart from this, Mudaliar was knighted in the 1945 New Year Honours. In 1954, he was awarded the Padma Bhushan and the Padma Vibhushan in 1963.
